article.title: GeoMesa: Getting Started
article.subtitle: pertaining to version of the API

section.title: Overview
section.para: The purpose of GeoMesa is to provide developers an API to store large volumes of spatio-temporal data in a Accumulo NoSQL database so that those data may be queried efficiently. The library largely follows conventions established by the GeoTools library.
The remainder of this document is organized by task:

listitem.para: installation and configuration
creating a DataStore
searching for features
creating a SimpleFeature
writing features
ingesting Shapefiles

section.title: Installation and Configuration
section.para: These are the main categories of use, each of which has specific installation instructions: allowing Accumulo to see the GeoMesa library; enabling GeoMesa support within GeoServer; preparing to write, compile, and run new Java code using the GeoMesa API.
The prerequisite to all of these tasks is having downloaded and unpacked the distribution tar-ball, geomesa-dist- -distribution.tar.gz.

section.title: Updating Accumulo Libraries
section.para: Copy everything from the unpacked accumulo/lib/ext directory to the ${ACCUMULO_HOME}/lib/ext directory on every tablet-server within your Accumulo installation.

It should not be necessary to restart either the tablet servers or Accumulo itself; the libraries should be automatically detected and enabled. We have confirmed that this works with version 1.5.1 of Accumulo.

section.title: Enabling GeoMesa support within GeoServer
section.para: GeoMesa includes a plugin for GeoServer that is compatible and tested with the 2.5.x GeoServer line. Follow the steps below to enable GeoMesa support within GeoServer:

formalpara.title: Step 1: Unpackage the GeoMesa tarball
formalpara.para: After building GeoMesa locate the distribution tarball and decompress it to a temporary directory: tar xvf geomesa-dist-accumulo1.5-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT-distribution.tar.gz

formalpara.title: Step 2: Deploy the GeoMesa plugin
formalpara.para: Copy the GeoMesa plugin from the lib directory to the GeoServer lib directory: cp geoserver/WEB-INF/lib/geomesa-plugin-accumulo1.5-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT-geoserver-plugin.jar \ ${GEOSERVER_HOME}/webapps/geoserver/WEB-INF/lib

formalpara.title: Step 3: Deploy dependencies
formalpara.para: GeoMesa needs several dependencies at runtime within GeoServer: accumulo-core accumulo-trace accumulo-fate zookeeper libthrift hadoop-common hadoop-mapreduce-client-core commons-configuration commons-vfs2 These are support services that are referenced by GeoMesa, yet are part of your base infrastructure. Use the most recent versions found in the distribution tarball. To deploy them simply copy them into your lib directory for the GeoServer webapp: cp dev/lib/<jar-name> ${GEOSERVER_HOME}/webapps/geoserver/WEB-INF/lib]

formalpara.title: Step 4: Upgrade shared dependencies
formalpara.para:
GeoMesa currently shares logging and codec libraries with GeoServer but uses newer versions: commons-logging commons-codec slf4j* Previous versions of these libraries need to be removed from the GeoServer classpath and new versions should be deployed: Whenever upgrading libraries, always keep a backup copy and then deploy new dependencies (example for GeoServer 2.5.1): # backup old libraries cd ${GEOSERVER_HOME} cp lib/slf4j-simple-1.0.1.jar /tmp/backup/ cp lib/commons-logging-1.0.jar /tmp/backup/ cp webapps/geoserver/WEB-INF/lib/commons-codec-1.2.jar /tmp/backup/
# deploy new libraries cd ${GEOMESA_DIST} cp dev/lib/commons-logging-1.1.1.jar ${GEOSERVER_HOME}/lib/ cp dev/lib/commons-codec-1.8.jar ${GEOSERVER_HOME}/webapps/geoserver/WEB-INF/lib/

section.title: Preparing for Development
section.para: Ensure that everything from the unpacked dev directory is on your Java classpath. These libraries will all be needed when developing new applications that use GeoMesa.

section.title: Creating a DataStore
section.para: The general model for working with spatial features is well described in the GeoTools documentation. The high-level ideas are these:

listitem.para: GeoTools organizes geospatial data into features. A feature might be a single point, line, polygon, etc. Each feature can have additional attributes beyond its geometry, such as a name, a price, a date, …
Features that share a description — a collection of attributes, each of which is named and typed — constitute a feature-type.

A DataStore is an object responsible for a single repository that may contain multiple feature types. To encourage generality, GeoTools provides a DataStoreFinder that can return (or create) a DataStore that is appropriate for a given set of parameters. We will describe the parameters required to fetch a AccumuloDataStore later.

The FeatureSource and FeatureStore objects are handed down from the DataStore, and are specific to a single feature type. The FeatureSource (generally) provides a read-only query mechanism, and the FeatureStore allows for writing features back to the DataStore.

section.para: To fetch a data store, the DataStoreFinder expects a Map<String,String> that contains these properties (all are required unless explicitly stated otherwise):

listitem.para: instanceId: this is the name of your Accumulo instance
zookeepers: this is a comma-separated list of host:port pairs; for example, "zoo1:2181,zoo2:2181,zoo3:2181"
user: this is a Accumulo user that can at least read, write, and create tables
password: this is the Accumulo userâ€™s password
auths: these are the cell-level authorizations that should be used with feature data; these should be expressed as comma-separated lists of values such as "A,B,C"

tableName: each DataStore is tied to a specific table within Accumulo, though the same data store/table can host multiple feature types. This table will be created, and initialized, if it does not already exist. Best practice is not to create this table yourself.

useMock: [optional; defaults to "false"] when set to "true", this option causes the data store to operate against a local, MockAccumulo instance instead of the real Accumulo instance; useful for testing

Note that fields such as geom and dtg are used in GeoMesa's spatio-temporal index scheme, in addition to being simple feature attributes in their own right. The selection of the fields for the indexing is done in this fashion:
Geometry: Select a field whose name is preceded by an asterisk, or failing that, the first geometry field described in the SimpleFeatureType, as the default geometry field. This field must always have a non-NULL value expressed in terms of SRID 4326
Time (Optional): Select a field whose name is taken from the map obtained using the method getUserData() on the SimpleFeatureType. In this map, the key Constants.SF_PROPERTY_START_TIME points to the relevant name. If no value is found, the first Date field found in the SimpleFeatureType itself is selected.

For relatively small feature collections — fewer than about one thousand items — ingest will write the entries directly to the Accumulo table. For larger collections, ingest will defer to a map/reduce job to organize the features for insertion. The next section describes how to configure GeoMesa to run in a map/reduce context.

section.title: Configuring GeoMesa for Map-Reduce
section.para: Some of the GeoMesa services, such as ingesting Shapefiles, may require support for map-reduce jobs. The GeoMesa map/reduce classes are packaged into JAR files within the expanded hdfs directory inside the distribution tar-ball. By default, GeoMesa will look for these JAR files within HDFS in the /geomesa/lib directory. Either copy the JARs to that directory within HDFS, or follow these steps to customize the location where GeoMesa will search for these classes:

listitem.para:
create a new, blank XML file called geomesa-site.xml somewhere on your Java classpath
It is possible to add entries to an existing Hadoop configuration file such as core-site.xml, but it is probably simpler to manage these custom properties if they remain in their own, separate file.

Re-run your Java application, being sure to pass in the following property:
-Dgeomesa.config.file=/your/path/geomesa-site.xml
If you receive a warning about the configuration file not being available, then it is likely that one of these issues exists:
the name of the file you specified in the Java property at run-time was not the same as the path, name of the configuration file you created;
the name of the file you specified is not accessible on the Java classpath;
there are file, directory permission conflicts
